questions.text: Beta-I, 3-D glucan assay test is used to diagnose all excepts-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mucormycosis Beta 3 glucan assay is used to detect the presence of beta 3 glucan in the fungal cell wall. It is used for Invasive candidiasis, Aspergillosis, Pneumocystis cranii but not for Mucormycosis. Beta-(1,3)-d-glucan (BG) detection is an emerging tool to diagnose invasive fungal infections (IFIs). Beta 3 glucan assay test is used to detect the presence of beta 3 glucan in the fungal cell wall. It is used mainly for CAP: C andidiasis A spergillosis P neumocystis

Highyeild:

Serological diagnosis of fungal infections. 1,3 B-D-glucan Galactomannan Pathogens + Inference Most fungi excluding mucor and crytococci. Primarily studied for candida, aspergillosis, and pneumocystis Most specific for diagnosing invasive aspergillosis (IA), reacts inconsistently in other fungi 4 False positives²: ● Patients on hemodialysis (cellulose membranes) ● Glucan-containing gauzes and surgical sponges, surgical patients ● Albumin infusions ● Some beta-lactams False positives: ● Beta lactam antibiotics ● Guar gum and soy polysaccharides (both in enteral nutrition) ● Foods (tea, milk, pasta, rice, pepper) ● Aspiration pneumonia ● VPLASMALYTE7,8 (IV and BAL) Test Characteristics Se Sp Proven or probable IA Se Sp At risk for PJP3 96 84 Serum⁹ 61 93 Immunosupp IFI3 80 82 BAL10 87 89 ICU IFI3 91-100 57-94 Study populations: Hematologic malignancy population, fewer studies in solid organ transplant patients. BDG studied in patients with suspected pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP). Fewer studies of BDG in non-neutropenic ICU patients.

options.label: A
options.text: It is type of helper T cells

options.label: B
options.text: It is an antigen presenting cell

options.label: C
options.text: It resides in gastrointestinal tract epithelium

questions.correct_answer: C. It resides in gastrointestinal tract epithelium
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It resides in gastrointestinal tract epithelium Gamma delta T cells (γδ T cells) are T cells that have a distinctive T-cell receptor (TCR) on their surface. This group of T cells is usually less common (5%) than αβ T cells, but are at their highest abundance in the gut mucosa, within a population of lymphocytes known as intraepithelial lymphocytes. Lack both CD4 and CD8 and are part of the innate immune system.

Solution:

Scrub Typhus The given Image is Trombiculid mite which is a vector of Chiggerosis or scrub typhus which is caused by Orientia Tsutsugamushi. It causes fever, myalgia and black eschar. Scrub typhus is transmitted to humans and rodents by some species of trombiculid mites (“chiggers”). The mite is small (0.2 – 0.4mm) and can only be seen through a microscope or magnifying glass. Humans acquire the disease from the bite of an infected chigger. The bite of the mite leaves a characteristic black eschar that is useful to the doctor for making the diagnosis. The adult mites have a four-stage life cycle: egg, larva, nymph and adult. The larva is the only stage (chigger) that can transmit the disease to humans and other vertebrates, since the other life stages (nymph and adult) do not feed on vertebrate animals . Both the nymph and the adult are free-living in the soil.

questions.text: For which of the following is PPV 23 most beneficial?

options.label: C
options.text: Patient with recurrent rhinitis and sinusitis

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sickle cell anemia Repeated micro infarctions can destroy tissues having microvascular beds prone to sickling. Thus splenic function is frequently lost within 18-36 months of life causing susceptibility to infection particularly by pneumococci. So PPV 23 vaccine is beneficial in sickle cell anemia. CDC recommends routine administration of pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13 or PCV15) for all children younger than 2 years of age: Give PCV13 or PCV15 to infants as a series of 4 doses, one dose at each of these ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, and 12 through 15 months.

questions.text: Patient has recovered from a hepatitis B infection. Identify the serological marker shown by the arrow in the Image below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anti HBc Appears at the onset of symptoms in acute hepatitis B infection and persists for life. The presence of anti-HBc indicates previous or ongoing infection with HBV.

Solution:

BTK BTK gene is involved in Burton’s disease or X linked agammaglobulinemia. Most cases of X linked SCID are due to mutations in IL 2 RG gene. Other mutations are defective enzyme production in Adenosine Deaminase (ADA) and mutations in ZAP 70 which causes defective T cell signaling which causes combined immunodeficiency and mutation occurs in JAK-3.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms cause multiple alveolar-like mass in liver?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Echinococcus multilocularis Echinococcus multilocularis causes multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver k/a Alveolar Hydatid disease/ Alveolar Echinococcosis. multilocularis leads to multilocular hydatid cyst, most commonly affecting the liver. It presents with multiple small cysts in the liver with no fluid or free brood capsules/scolices. Often associated with central necrosis and cavitation. Cyst appear as solid firm mass with an irregular outer layer with ability to migrate rapidly to other organs, miming as malignant tumor and spread directly or through blood and lymphatics. E granulosus causes Cystic Echinococcosis E vogeli causes Polycystic Echinococcosis/Hydatid disease.

Highyeild:

LIFECYCLE

questions.text: A 25-Year-old man presents with urethral discharge for the last three days. A gram stained smear of the discharge is shown in the Image. All of the following are true about the likely etiology excepts-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Obligate Intracellular The given gram stain shows gram-negative diplococci within the polymorphs which is characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. Neisseria is not an obligate intracellular organism, it can also occur extracellularly i.e. facultative intracellular. Image shows N. gonorrhoeae which have pili as a virulence factor and are both catalase and oxidase positive and show slow twitching (slow kind of motility). N. gonorrhoeae, though predominantly intracellular but not strictly intracellular.

questions.text: A Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral blood smear is prepared. Which of the following cannot be diagnosed?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Coxiella burnetii A diagnosis of Coxiella burnetii cannot be done using a Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear. The diagnosis of Coxiella burnetii is done mainly by serology which shows a rise in the titer of specific antibodies to C. burnetii. Coxiella burnetii is an obligate intracellular bacterial pathogen, and is the causative agent of Q fever.

questions.text: Which of the following toxin acts by this mechanism shown in the Image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Botulism The Image given above depicts the mechanism of action of Botulinum toxin. Mechanism of action of botulinum toxin: Botulinum toxin acts by binding presynaptically to high-affinity recognition sites on the cholinergic nerve terminals and decreasing the release of acetylcholine, causing a neuromuscular blocking effect. Botulinum toxin contains 2 chains: Heavy and light. The heavy chain binds presynaptically to nerve terminals and is responsible for mediating translocation of light chain into the cell. The light chain is active part which cleaves host protein SNAP 25. The cleaved SNAP 25 prevents the release of neurotransmitter Acetylcholine and is responsible for flaccid paralysis. Tetanus toxin causes cleavage of synaptobrevin and prevents the release of neurotransmitters GABA and glycine which causes spastic paralysis. Diphtheria toxin causes ADP ribosylation of elongating factor 2 which inhibits protein synthesis.

questions.text: The CLED medium is preferred over other media for the culture of the organisms in case of UTI because.-

options.label: C
options.text: It helps growth of candida and Staphylococcus

questions.correct_answer: C. It helps growth of candida and Staphylococcus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It helps growth of candida and Staphylococcus Cysteine-, lactose-, electrolyte-deficient (CLED) agar promotes the growth of Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, and Candida and is less inhibitory and like staphylococcus, streptococcus after bacteria. It is used as an alternative to the combination of blood agar and MacConkey agar for the processing of urine specimens. Cysteine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient Agar (CLED) is a non selective media and it stimulates the growth of staphylococcus and candida whereas MacConkey agar is a selective media. Both CLED and MacConkey Agar inhibits the swarming of proteus and differentiates between lactose fermenter and non lactose fermenter. Both use sodium taurocholate as a selective agent and so option (c) is a better option. Hence CLED is an important media which combines benefits of both Blood agar and MacConkey’s agar in one media eliminating the need of putting culture on blood agar additionally saving time and media requirement for processing urinary sample and isolation of uropathogen.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of toxin produced by the bacterium shown in the Image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ADP-ribosylation of EF-2 Given Image shows gram – positive rods with club shaped end, beaded appearance & Chinese letter pattern of arrangement indicating corynebacterium diphtheriae. Diphtheria toxin causes ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2 which inhibits protein synthesis.
